question: How do you know when a problem involves ethics?
answers: If you are forced to consider where your obligations and duties lie
If it raises moral problems for you or a coworker
When a correct and incorrect response is not clear
helper: A problem involves ethics when it raises any of the issues listed above.

question: All city employees are also considered public employees.
helper: Any individual employed by the City of Pittsburgh in any capacity is a city employee, but not all city employees are considered public employees.

question: There is no real difference between a Public Employee and a Public Official.
helper: A Public Official is elected by the public or an appointed official in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania or any political subdivision, except for members of advisory boards with no authority to expend public funds.  A Public Employee is an individual employed by the Commonwealth or political subdivision who is responsible for taking official action of a non-ministerial nature.

question: Which of the answers below describes a person who is not considered within the definition of either an Immediate or Direct Family member?
helper: Immediate family includes a parent, spouse or domestic partner, child, or sibling. Direct Family includes step-parents, step-children or step-siblings, grandparents, grandchildren, parents-in-law, siblings-in-law, aunts, uncles and first cousins.

question: An interested party is defined as:
answers: A person having or seeking to obtain a contract, grant, employment or any financial relationship with the City
A principal, agent or attorney in legal proceedings in which the City is then an adverse party
A person with an interest that may be substantially affected by the performance or nonperformance of the official duties of the public official or city employee
helper: All of the above.

question: What can you do to make sure you know whether you are acting responsibly and professionally to further the public's trust?
helper: All of the above.  Knowing your rights and responsibilities assures that government officials and employees can put aside their personal interest and promote the public's interest.

question: Jack and Joe are both City employees.  Jack is married to Joe’s sister.  Joe gives Jack a Christmas gift worth $150.00.  Can Jack accept the gift?
helper: City employees may give gifts to one another if they are in recognition of a special occasion, illness or holiday.   The fact that Jack and Joe are brothers-in-law would not exempt them from giving and accepting gifts because they are not immediate family members.  The gift is permissible because it is for a special occasion, illness or holiday.

question: Jack is a Public Official.  Jack’s brother-in-law, Joe, is a City Employee.   Joe gives Jack a Christmas gift worth $150.00.  Can Jack accept the gift?
helper: Jack may accept the gift, but because Jack is a Public Official and Joe is not an immediate family member, Jack must disclose the gift because the value exceeds $100.00.

question:
Mary is a Public Official who was presented with an award for her dedication and commitment to improving after school programs. The award would be given in the form of a plaque and presented publicly in recognition of her public service. This award is nonpecuniary (not related to money). 
 Would Mary be violating the Offering, Soliciting or Accepting Gifts rule if she accepts the award?
helper: If the gift does not relate to money and it is presented publicly for recognition of public service, then Mary can accept the gift.

question: As an exception to the Offering, Soliciting or Accepting of Gifts rule, Employees are permitted to attend public events or ceremonies sponsored by non-profit organizations that offer valuables such as admission, attendance, food and refreshment. In this exception, employees are limited to ______ tickets per employee per event.
helper: Employees are limited to two (2) tickets per employee per event when offered an invitation by a sponsoring organization to a public event. This exception is not to exceed four (4) events per year from the same organization or individual.

question: Sherry, a public employee in the department of I & P is working with Anita, who is employed by a company who contracts with the City and provides services to Sherry’s department.  Sherry and Anita have become friends.  Anita has invited Sherry, Sherry’s husband and two children to a baseball game.  The tickets were provided by Anita’s company at no cost to Sherry. May Sherry accept the tickets?
helper: A public employee shall not accept anything of value from any person or entity that the public employee knows, or has reason to know is an interested party.  None of the exceptions apply.

question: What if, in the previous question, Sherry was attending the game as a guest of the sponsoring organization (Anita’s company) in Sherry’s official capacity with the City?  May she accept the tickets under those circumstances?
helper: This exception is limited to two (2) tickets per employee per event, not to exceed four (4) events per year from the same organization or individual.  Sherry may only accept two of the four tickets offered.  In addition, Sherry must disclose the gift if the value of the tickets exceeds $100.

question: Brenda is employed by the City in the Department of Public Works.  In performing her job duties, a city resident offers Brenda an expensive bottle of wine as a gratuity.  May Brenda accept the wine as a gratuity?
helper: No city employee shall receive any compensation, gratuity or other thing for an act done while performing public work.

question:
Jessica has worked for the City for 15 years. Jessica’s aunt, Betty, is also a city employee in the same department. Jessica was just promoted to the position of Director of the department. A promotion opportunity under her direct supervision presents itself and Jessica decides to promote Betty over a much higher qualified employee to the position. 
 Has Jessica engaged in an act which constitutes an ethical violation?
helper: No public employee shall appoint, hire, advance or advocate the appointment, hiring or advancing a member of his or her direct family to a City position. Since Betty is a direct member of Jessica’s family, promoting Betty would be prohibited without first obtaining a waiver of the rule by the Ethics Hearing Board.

question: Councilwoman, Carrie Hunter, just hired her step-son, Jim Hunter, as her Chief of Staff. Is this permitted under the City of Pittsburgh’s Ethics Code?
helper: This violates the rule regarding the Employment or Appointment of Relatives, which states that a direct family member of a public official or public employee shall not be appointed, hired or advanced to a position which is under the direct jurisdiction or control of that public official or public employee.

question:
It is discovered that a high-ranking City Official made a deal with the general manager of Acme Security Firm, a City contractor, to provide personal security for the City Official’s special guests when they visited the City for business meetings. In exchange for these after-hours services, the City Official graciously offered the general manager the use of his vacation home at a local ski resort. 
 Which statement is correct?
answers: There is no ethical violation because nothing of value was exchanged.
The general manager is an Interested Party and as such, the City Official violated the Offering, Soliciting or Accepting Gifts rule
There was no ethical violation because this was a nonpecuniary gift between the City Official and the general manager
This violated the rule prohibiting the use of authority and public property
correct: The general manager is an Interested Party and as such, the City Official violated the Offering, Soliciting or Accepting Gifts rule
helper: A Public Official, Public Employee, or City Employee shall not solicit or accept anything of value from any person or entity that the Public Official, Public Employee, or City Employee knows or has reason to know, is an Interested Party.

question: Janet was terminated from her position as a City solicitor in October 2016. Six months later, Janet has opened her own law practice and is representing a client who she formerly represented for the City, now suing the City for employment discrimination.
helper: Janet is required to wait for a period of 12 months from the time her employment or service was terminated, before representing a person, with or without compensation, on a matter before the governmental body with which she had been associated.

module: Conflict of Interest & Misuse of Authority
question:
Sherry is a City employee in charge of booking a caterer for a City charity event. She chooses to book her brother’s catering business for the event because then both the City and her brother can benefit from the event. 
 Has Sherry violated the Conflict of Interest rule by hiring her brother’s company for her employer’s event?
helper: Sherry has exerted influence with respect to a business with which she or a member of her direct family is associated. This is a conflict of interest.

module: Conflict of Interest & Misuse of Authority
question: Tom is a Public Official.  Tom is involved in a matter which requires him to vote to approve an expenditure payable to a company that does business with Tom’s wife’s company.  What is Tom’s responsibility to do in this situation?
answers: Abstain from the vote and publicly announce the nature of the interest prior to the vote
Vote then publicly announce the nature of the interest
Do nothing, there is no conflict of interest
correct: Abstain from the vote and publicly announce the nature of the interest prior to the vote
helper: Tom must abstain from the vote and publicly announce the nature of the interest prior to the vote.

module: Conflict of Interest & Misuse of Authority
question:
Bradley is a City Council member who is up for re-election. He makes a deal with a Taylor Construction Inc., promising to sign a 2-year contract with them after he is re-elected so long as they endorse and vote for him. 
 Has Bradley violated any rules of ethics?
helper: Bradley will use his position to create a benefit for his personal interest of being re-elected for City Council.

module: Conflict of Interest & Misuse of Authority
question:
Connie is a member of the Zoning Board and a member of the Rotary Club. The Zoning Board is discussing a plan to enter a contract with the Rotary Club which will require Connie to give input and vote.  The contract would provide the Rotary Club with much needed funds to carry-on some of the Club’s charitable work. 
 Does Connie have to disclose her relationship with the Rotary Club?
helper: Connie has a conflict of Interest.  Connie is required to disclose on the record the nature and extent of the interest that exists.

module: Conflict of Interest & Misuse of Authority
question:
John is a City Building Inspector. He also has his own private business working as a contractor on the side. While he is on the job for the City and visiting job sites for inspections, he hands out his personal business cards and suggests the property owners give him a call for any contracting work they may need in the future. 
 Is John engaging in an act that constitutes an ethical violation?
helper: John is engaging in Misuse of Authority by using City time and clients to benefit his own personal business. This rule prohibits the use of any City facilities, property, staff, or information obtained during his employment for personal use other than would be generally available to the public at large.

module: Conflict of Interest & Misuse of Authority
question:
Refer back to the previous question (about John, the City Building Inspector) to answer this: 
 Would it make a difference if John returned to the same job sites after hours to hand out his personal business cards to the property owners to solicit business for his own private company?
helper: It is still a Misuse of Authority for John to use his City position to benefit his private business, even if the solicitation occurs after hours.  The source of potential customers was information obtained during his employment.

module: Conflict of Interest & Misuse of Authority
question: Matt is a city employee in the department of City Planning.  Matt has a degree in Urban Planning from a prestigious university.  In addition to his job at the city, Matt has a consulting business as an urban planner.  Matt had business cards printed for his consulting business on which he included his official title as “City Planner for the City of Pittsburgh.”  Has Matt broken any rules?
helper: No city employee shall use or permit the use of his or her official title, insignia or position in connection with any private business from which the employee receives compensation.

module: Conflict of Interest & Misuse of Authority
question: No City employee shall contribute more than _______ during any consecutive four-year period to any political campaign of his or her employer or to any political campaign of his or her employing authority.
helper: No more than $100. However, Directors of Departments, the Mayor’s Executive Secretary Officer and the Chief Administrative Officer are permitted two hundred dollars ($200.00) for any four-year period.
